It was decided in Fernando Vs Wijesooriya 48 NLR 320. “there must be a corporeal occupation of
land attended with a manifest intention to hold and continue it and when the intent specifically is
to hold the land against the claim of all other persons, the possession is hostile or adverse to the
rights of the true owner.  It is the intention to claim the title which makes the possession of the
holder of the land adverse – if it be clear that there is no such intention, there can be no pretense
of adverse possession.”
